skills.name: Identify the constant of proportionality from a linear graph
Identify the constant of proportionality from a linear equation
Identify the constant of proportionality from a table of values

explanations.A: You have accidentally found the relationship that relates ğ‘¥ to ğ‘¦. We are looking for the relationship that relates ğ‘¦ to ğ‘¥!
explanations.B: Not all straight lines have a gradient of 1... Find ğ‘¦ / ğ‘¥ to get the constant of proportionality!
explanations.C: Picking some coordinates from the graph: (4, 8), (10, 20) etc. we can see to go from ğ‘¥ to ğ‘¦ we multiply by 2! Therefore, ğ‘¦ = 2ğ‘¥ and the constant of proportionality is 2.
explanations.D: One of the coordinates on the graph is (10, 20). They have a multiplicative relationship, not additive. What do you times ğ‘¥ by to get ğ‘¦?

explanations.A: Picking some coordinates from the graph: (2, 10), (6, 30) etc. we can see to go from ğ‘¥ to ğ‘¦ we multiply by 5! Therefore, ğ‘¦ = 5ğ‘¥ and the constant of proportionality is 5.
explanations.B: One of the coordinates on the graph is (1, 5). They have a multiplicative relationship, not additive. What do you times ğ‘¥ by to get ğ‘¦?
explanations.C: You have accidentally found the relationship that relates ğ‘¥ to ğ‘¦. We are looking for the relationship that relates ğ‘¦ to ğ‘¥!
explanations.D: Not all straight lines have a gradient of 1... Find ğ‘¦ / ğ‘¥ to get the constant of proportionality!

explanations.A: You have accidentally found the relationship that relates ğ‘¥ to ğ‘¦. We are looking for the relationship that relates ğ‘¦ to ğ‘¥!
explanations.B: I think you have confused the constant of proportionality with the ğ‘¦-intercept in ğ‘¦ = ğ‘šğ‘¥ + ğ‘! In this question, the constant of proportionality is what you multiply ğ‘¥ by to get ğ‘¦...
explanations.C: We can see the coordinate (10, 4) lies on the line. To get the constant of proportionality we do ğ‘¦ / ğ‘¥ which equals 4 / 10. This simplifies to 2/5 therefore, the constant of proportionality is 2/5!
explanations.D: The coordinate (5, 12) doesn't actually lie on the line. Choose a coordinate that does and repeat this same method to get the constant of proportionality!
